INTRODUCTION

Ever since the recommendation of the CIECAM02 colour?appearance model by CIE TC 8?01 ?Colour appearancemodeling for colour management systems,? it has been used to predict colour appearance under a widerange of viewing conditions,to specify colour appearance in terms of perceptual attributes, figure 2to quantify colour differences,to propose a uniform colour spaceand to provide a profile connection space for colour management.However, Brill and Süsstrunkfound that CIECAM02 has the so?called yellow?blue and purple problems illustrated by Figs.and. Figureshows the built?in CAT02 triangle (formed by three solid lines), the HPE triangle (formed by dottedcolour lines), and the CIE spectrum locus and purple line (dotted black line) inu?,v?space. The three vertices for the corresponding triangles in Fig.are called the red, green and blue primary points, as discussed by Liet al.and reviewed briefly in the next section. The so?called purple problem is originated because the largepart of the purple region of the CAT02 triangle including the CAT02 blue primary point is located insidethe domain enclosed by the spectrum locus and purple line. However, the so?called yellow?blue problemoccurs on the long wavelength spectrum locus side, where it seems that the spectrum locus and the bluedotted and solid lines are overlapping, although in fact, they are not. The blow?up of this part isshown in Fig., where we can see that the dotted blue line is located inthe middle, which is the source of the yellow?blue problem. Figuresandalso illustrate why the purple and yellow?blue problems are bad, respectively. Specifically, the markers?x? represent input sample colours to theCAT02 under the test source, and after the CAT02transform withD?=?1, the output (orcorresponding) colours under the reference source are locatedat the positions indicated by the markers ?+?. The tristimulus values for the input samples ?x,?the test and reference illuminants, and the output samples ?+? (corresponding colours) from the CAT02are listed in Table. The original figure 3 colours under the test illuminant(marked as ?x? in Figs.and) were transformed to the positions ?+? outside the HPE triangleafter adaptation to the reference illuminant, which produces negative values in some of CIECAM02R?G?B?coordinates. There are two adaptations in CIECAM02. The first is a chromatic adaptation using the CAT02matrix, and the second is a luminance adaptation in the cone space using the transform(R?G?B?)=M(XcYcZc),whereMis the Hunt?Pointer?Estévez (HPE) matrix given by:MHPE=[0.389710.68898?0.07869?0.229811.183400.046410.000000.000001.00000],andXc,Yc, andZcare the tristimulus values of the corresponding colours. In Figs.andthe original colours were transformed by the CAT02 matrix toXc,Yc, andZcwhich are outside the HPE triangle, and therefore some of theR?,G?, orB?responses will be negative. This may cause computational instability and unexpected computationalfailure.In fact, CIECAM02 uses the non?linear luminance adaptationRa?=sign(R?)*400(FL|R?|/100)0.4227.13+(FL|R?|/100)0.42+0.1for the red channel, and similar equations for the ref 3 other channels. However, the nonlinear functionf(t)=sign(t)400(t)0.4227.13+(t)0.42+0.1has an infinite slope whent?=?0, whichcauses instabilityfor the inverse model. The computational failure might come from the computation of the lightnessJusing the formulae:J=100(A/Aw)czandA=[2R?a+G?a+(1/20)B?a?0.305]Nbb.

WhileAwwas shown to be positive,Acan be negative when theR?,G?, orB? response is negative, which causesanunexpected computational failure.

Brill and Süsstrunkgave a solution to the yellow?blue problem by replacing the CAT02 matrixM02=[0.73280.4296?0.1624?0.70361.69750.00610.00300.01360.9834]??by:MBS=[0.73280.4296?0.1624?0.70361.69750.0061001].

Unfortunately, with this change, the purple problem remains. Brill and Süsstrunkpointed out that the purple problem is difficult, and gave a nesting rule to solve the yellow?blue andpurple problems simultaneously, i.e., ?for all corresponding colours to lie inside the HPE triangle,three chromaticity sets must be nested: The HPE triangle must encompass the (modified) CAT02 triangle,which in turn must encompass the spectrum locus?.

Liet al.considered modifying the CAT02 matrix so that theR,G, andBresponses (obtained by multiplying tristimulus values as column vector by the CAT02 matrix, as shown inEq.below) or theR?,G?, andB? responses in Eq.were always non?negative, and they found that when the CAT02 matrix in Eq.is replaced by the HPE matrix in Eq., theR?,G?, andB? responses in Eq.are always non?negative. Liet al.further explored the advantages and disadvantage of this change. The advantages were: (a) the modifiedversion of the CIECAM02 was simpler than the original CIECAM02; (b) all mathematical inconsistencieswere overcome when the input samples had chromaticity inside the domain enclosed by the spectrum locusand purple line. The disadvantage was that the modified version of CIECAM02 could not predict thecorresponding colour data sets as well as the original CIECAM02, which in fact was an expected resultsince the original CAT02 matrixwas derived to achieve the best fit of the corresponding colour data sets.Note that when the CAT02 matrix is replaced by the HPE matrix, the nesting rule specified by Brill andSüsstrunk is satisfied. Recently, Liet al.revisited the CAT02 and HPE triangles and found that there are many matrices (including the HPE matrixitself) which can replace the CAT02 matrix and satisfy the nesting rule.

The main goal of the current paper is to find an optimal matrix satisfying the nesting rule (i.e.,solving simultaneously the yellow?blue and purple problems) and fitting as well as possible mostcurrently available corresponding colour data sets.To this end, in next section, the chromatic adaptation matrix and its red, green, and blue primaries areinvestigated. Linear equations linking the matrix coefficients and thex,yoru?,v?chromaticity coordinates of the primaries are given. Based on these equations, thex,yoru?,v?chromaticity coordinates of the red, green, and blue primaries can be obtained if the matrix is given.Also, if thex,yoru?,v?chromaticity coordinates of the three primaries and a postulated white point are given, the matrixcoefficients can be determined, which is the foundation for modeling the optimum solution to theyellow?blue and purple problems as an optimization problem. In the section ?Possible primaries andcoordinates for the modified CAT02 matrix,? the constraints for the chromaticity coordinates of theprimaries and matrix satisfying the nesting rule are studied. In the section ?Fitting the visualexperimental data,? a two?variable objective function involving visual experimental datasets is proposedfor optimization. In the section ?The optimum solution,? MATLAB is used to solve the constrainednon?linear optimization problem and an optimum solution (that is, a new CAT02 matrix) is found. Finally,the section ?Conclusions? contains the main conclusions.

CHROMATIC ADAPTATION MATRIX AND ITS CORRESPONDING PRIMARIES

LetMbe a chromatic adaptation matrix with the general formM=(m11m12m13m21m22m23m31m32m33).

The transform(RGB)=M(XYZ)=(m11X+m12Y+m13Zm21X+m22Y+m23Zm31X+m32Y+m33Z)maps tristimulus valuesX,Y,andZinXYZcolour system to tristimulus valuesR,G, andBin theRGBcolour system. Note that if matrixMof Eq.is the CAT02 matrix of Eq., theRGBcolour system is the shaper sensor space, but if matrixMof Eq.is the HPE matrix given by Eq., theRGBcolour system is the cone space.Usually, the reference white stimulus can be matched by the mixture of one unit of all three primarycolours in bothRGBandXYZcolour systems, which implies that coefficients of matrixMhave the next constraints:(111)=M(111)=(m11+m12+m13m21+m22+m23m31+m32+m33).

These constraints were used for deriving the CAT02and CMCCAT2000matrices. The CAT02 matrix of Eq., the HPE matrix of Eq.and the Bradford transformsatisfy Eq.. Note that in fact the first row of the HPE matrix in CIEPublication 159:2004does not satisfy the above constraint, which might be caused by rounding errors using different numberof decimal digits. To meet the constraints given by Eq., here we haveused the coefficient ?0.07869 in matrixMHPE(see Eq.) in place of ?0.07868 given in CIE Publication 159:2004,following the suggestion from Liet al.

Next we consider how to express one unit of red primary colour ofRGBcolour system in theXYZcolour system. Since one unit of red primary colour ofRGBcolour system means the tristimulus values areR?=?1,G?=?0, andB?=?0 in Eq., for the redprimary the tristimulus valuesX,Y,andZinXYZsystem must satisfy:(100)=M(XYZ)=(m11X+m12Y+m13Zm21X+m22Y+m23Zm31X+m32Y+m33Z).

ConsideringSXYZbeing different from zero, from Eq.it follows:(1/SXYZ00)=M(xyz)=(m11x+m12y+m13zm21x+m22y+m23zm31x+m32y+m33z).

From the above discussions, it is clear that, for any given matrixM, the chromaticity coordinatesof its primary colours and corresponding triangle can be obtained. The reverse is also true, and matrixMcan be determined fromx,ychromaticity coordinates of the three primary colours. The nine coefficients in matrixMmust satisfy the constraints of Eq.. Hence, although each row inmatrixMhas three coefficients, only two are independent, in such a way that matrixMhas only six variables. The situation is similar to the previous one where the sixx,ychromaticity coordinates corresponding to the three primary colours were determined from the matrixcoefficients. The six independent coefficients for theMmatrix and its six independentx,ycoordinates satisfy Eqs.. Nomatter which set of six independent variables are given, the other set of six unknown variables can bedetermined from the six equations. In summary, from thex,ychromaticity coordinates of the three primary colours, it is possible to determine all coefficients ofmatrixM, which will make possible obtainingan optimum solution to the yellow?blue and purpleproblems, as discussed in next sections.

POSSIBLE PRIMARIES AND COORDINATES FOR THE MODIFIED CAT02 MATRIX

Figuresandshow the CAT02 matrix does not satisfy the nesting rule (i.e., the CAT02 triangle do not completelyincludes the region enclosed by the spectrum locus and purple line). Now we explore how to modify theCAT02 matrix so that the nesting rule is satisfied. Once again,first we have considered this problem in theu?,v? chromaticity coordinates space.Figureshows the HPE red, green, and blue primary pointsP23,P13, andP12, respectively, and its associatedtriangle formed by linking the three primary points(dotted coloured lines). The spectrum locus and purple line linking the two ends of the spectrum locus(black dotted lines) are also shown in Fig.. The pointP2(marked with downward triangle) was chosen so that the line linking the pointsP2andP12is tangent to the spectrum locus. The point P1(marked with upward triangle) is the intersection point of the extended purple line and the line linkingthe primary pointsP13andP23. Let the modified CAT matrix havenew blue, green, and red primary points designated asP12N,P13N,andP23N, respectively. In order to find thenew matrix satisfying the nesting rule,P12Nhas not much room to manoeuvre. It can be fixed to beP12. ForP23NandP13N, they must be on the line linkingthe two primary pointsP13andP23of the HPE matrix. If we chooseP23Nto beP1andP13Nto beP2, then we have for the modified matrixthe smallest triangle satisfying the nesting rule, asshown in Fig.. Obviously, if we chooseP23Nto beP23andP13Nto beP13, then we have for the modifiedmatrix the largest triangle satisfying the nesting rule, asalso shown in Fig.. In this last case, the modified CAT02 matrix isexactly the HPE matrix. In summary, in order to find a new CAT02 matrix satisfying the nesting rule, agood approximation is the three primary points satisfy the next three conditions:P12Nmay beP12;P23Nmust be on the blue line fromP1toP23inclusive;P13Nmust be on the blue line fromP2toP13inclusive.

Let the three primary pointsP12N,P13N,andP23Nfor the modified CAT02 matrix have chromaticity coordinates designated as (u?B,v?B), (u?G,v?G), and (u?R,v?R) inu?,v?space, respectively. Theu?,v?coordinates for pointsP1,P2,P12,P13,andP23will be designated as (u?1,v?1), (u?2,v?2), (u?12,v?12), (u?13,v?13), and (u?23,v?23), respectively, and are listed inTable. From conditionI), we know that the blue primary P12Nfor the modified CAT02 matrix is fixed to be the blue primaryP12of the HPE matrix. Thus, from Table, (u?B,v?B) is given by:(u?B,v?B)=(u?12,v?12)=(0.2523,0).

Furthermore, note that pointsP1,P2,P13,andP23as well as pointsP13N,P23N,andBinfare all on the same line defined byv?=Au?v?u?+Bu?v?,where the constants values are:Au?v?= ?3/20 andBu?v?=12/20. Thus, in fact we have only two independent variablesu?Gandu?Rrather than the original six variables (u?B,v?B), (u?G,v?G), and (u?R,v?R). Hence, from condition II) and Table, the coordinates (u?R,v?R) of the red primary should satisfy0.6234=u?1?u?R?u?23=1.0223,andv?Rcan be computed from Eq.whenu?Ris known. Similarly, from condition III) and Tablewe have?0.5344=u?13?u?G?u?2=?0.2202,andv?Gcan be computed from Eq.whenu?Gis known.

In summary, the three primary pointsP12N,P13N,andP23Nfor the modified CAT02 matrix have chromaticity coordinates (u?B,v?B), (u?G,v?G), and (u?R,v?R), inu?,v?space, satisfying condition I) specified by Eq., condition II)specified by Eq., and condition III) specified by Eq., respectively. Then, from values ofchromaticity coordinates (u?B,v?B), (u?G,v?G), and (u?R,v?R), the coefficients of the modified CAT02 matrix can be determined from Eqs., as discussed in theprevious section.

FITTING THE VISUAL EXPERIMENTAL DATA

From the discussions in the previous section, we know that the modified CAT02 matrixMin Eq.we try to propose has only two freedoms, i.e.Mcan be specified from theu?coordinates of the new red and green primaries,u?Randu?G. Thus,Mis a function of just two variables, and it can be represented asM(u?R,u?G). The variableu?Rmust satisfy the condition specified by Eq.while variableu?Gmust satisfy the condition specified by Eq.. It is clear that thereare many choices foru?Randu?Gand hence forM(u?R,u?G). For eachM(u?R,u?G), we have a modified CAT02 and a modified CIECAM02. In other words, the modified CAT02 is the newmatrixM(u?R,u?G) replacing the CAT02 original matrix in Eq., while the modifiedCIECAM02 is simply the built?in CAT02 original matrix in the original CIECAM02 model being replaced bythe modified CAT02.

Now we try to determine the values of these two variablesu?Randu?Gsuch that the modified CAT02 matrix fits best the corresponding colour data sets.

Corresponding colour data sets used here are the seven colour data sets earlier accumulated by Luo andHunt.These data sets are those from Lam and Rigg,the Colour Science Association of Japan (CSAJ),Kuoet al.,Helsonet al.,LUTCHI,Breneman,and Braun and Fairchild.Altogether, in overall these seven datasets provide 21 subsets and 584 pairs of colours. It can be saidthat these seven data sets of corresponding colours are the most reliable and comprehensive experimentaldata accumulated over the years and nowadays available. They were used for deriving the CAT02 matrix.The weighted mean?E¯of CIELAB colour differences between predictions of the modified CAT02 matrix and experimental visualresults is used here as a measure of the performance of the modified CAT02 matrix. The weights for thisweighted mean is the relative number of color pairs: The more color pairs the data set has, the largerweight it has, the sum of all weights being 1. It is clear that?E¯depends onu?Randu?G, and hence?E¯can be expressed as?E¯(u?R,u?G).

Now, the objective functionF(u?R,u?G)is defined by:F(u?R,u?G)=?E¯(u?R,u?G),and it must be minimized, with variablesu?Randu?Gsatisfying Eqs.andrespectively.

THE OPTIMUM SOLUTION

The MATLAB function fmincon was used to solve the mentioned constrained non?linear minimization problemof the function given in Eq.. First, the initial guess for the twovariables were chosen at the centers of the intervals established by Eqs.and. However, the automatic output message from MATLAB alerted us"local minimum possible, constraints satisfied" withu?R=0.6234 andu?G=?0.2871, and the objective functionF(u?R,u?G) had a value of 6.4791. Then, we randomly chose initial guess values uniformly distributed in theintervals specified by Eqs.and. It was found that for each run the variableu?Ralways stabilized at 0.6234, while the variableu?Gstabilized at different values between ?0.2874 and ?0.2860. However, although the optimum solution foru?Gchanges for each run, the associated objective functionF(u?R,u?G) had the same value of 6.4791. In fact, it was even found that whenu?Gwas in a wider range from ?0.2984 to ?0.2800, the associated objective function roughly had the sameprevious value. These results indicate that the variableu?Rshould be fixed at its lowest boundary of 0. 6234 [see Eq.and condition II)], which means that the red primary for the optimum modified CAT02 matrix should befixed at pointP1, as shown in Fig..Furthermore, the corresponding datasets are not sensitive to the values of variableu?Gin the range from ?0.2984 to ?0.2800. Note that this range includes the value ?4/14, theu?coordinate of point Binf, as shown inFig.and given in Table.

It seems that it is difficult to determine the optimum solution inu?,v? space. Theobjective functionF(u?R,u?G) is well defined withu?Rin the range from 0.6234 to 1.0223 [see Eq.] andu?Gin the range from ?0.5344 to ?0.2202 [see Eq.]. It is now clear that the minimum ofF(u?R,u?G) overthe range specified by Eqs.andwill be the minimum of the function g(u?G)=F(0.6234,u?G) overthe range specified by Eq.. The function g(u?G) isshown in Fig.. The marker circle point (withu?G=?4/14 and g(u?G)=6.4791) is the optimum pointselected for obtaining the matrixMOPTgiven by Eq.. This clearly shows the marker point is the trough of thefunction g(u?G) which shows the correctness ofour numerical optimization.

Figureshows the triangles corresponding to theMHPE[Eq.andMOPT(Eq.)] matrices. All the symbols have the same meanings as those inFig.. The dotted coloured lines form the HPE triangle, while the solidcoloured lines form the triangle associated to matrixMOPT. Note that the symbols diamond forBinfand circle forP13Noverlap, and the symbols upper triangle forP1and circle forP23Nalso overlap. Figureclearly shows that the nesting rule is satisfied.

Figureshows the nesting rule is also satisfied inx,yspace for theMOPTandMHPEmatrices. All the symbols have again the same meanings as those in Fig.. The red (green and blue) lines show theR(GandB) responses defined by Eq.being zero for theMHPE(dotted lines) andMOPT(solid lines) matrices. For theMHPEmatrix, any two of the associated three lines are not parallel, and hence the three primariesP12,P13,andP23can be determined. For theMOPTmatrix, both the red and green, and the blue and green lines are also not parallel, and hence the blueand red primariesP12NandP23Ncan be determined. However, the red and blue lines for theMOPTmatrix are parallel, and the green primary cannot be determined. The green primary in thex,yspace can be considered as an ?infinity point? along the direction of the blue line. Therefore, it isclear that there is a problem trying to define an associated triangle in Fig.by just linking the three primary points associated to matrixMOPT. In fact, there was already aproblem with the nesting rule when comparing the CAT02 andHPE matrices inx,yspace (see Fig.in ref. 11). The nesting rule in this case should be understood in terms of positive response domains.That is, if ?Mis the set of all points (x,y) (or (u?,v?)) so that theirR,G,andBresponses defined by Eq.for a matrixMdefined by Eq.are non?negative, and ?CIEis the domain enclosed by the spectral locus and purple line, the nesting rule should be exactly statedas:?CIE??OPT??HPE.

For example, in theu?,v? space, it can be shown in Fig.that ?OPTis the triangular region of red, blue and green solid lines formed by linking the three primary pointsP12N?=?P12,P13N?=?BinfandP23N?=?P1for the matrixMOPT, while ?HPEis the quadrilateral region formed by linking the four pointsP23,Binf,Rinf,andP12. Thus, the nesting rule in Eq.is satisfied according to Fig.. When inx,yspace, it can be shown in Fig.that ?OPTis the set of all (x,y) points below the solid blue line,above the solid green line andabove the solid red line, while ?HPEis the set of all (x,y) points below the dotted blue line(same as the solid blue line),above the dotted green line and above the dotted red line. Hence, in this last case the nesting rule inEq.is also satisfied.

Next, we have computed the spectral responses [obtained by multiplying the CIE 1931 colour?matchingfunctions, viewed as a column vector at each wavelength, by the corresponding matrix, as indicated inEq.] for theMOPTmatrix, and compared with those found from the HPE [Eq.] and CAT02[Eq.] matrices, as shown in Fig.. Forthe blue channel (blue lines) all three spectral responses are very similar. For the green channel, allresponses peak at approximately the same wavelengths, and the CAT02 and HPE matrices give the highestand lowest (positive) responses, respectively. The green response forMOPTis in between those for CAT02 and HPE matrices. For the red channel, responses peak at differentwavelengths. In general, the spectral responses forMOPT(dotted lines in Fig.) are more similar to those for the HPE matrix(thin lines in Fig.), and they are non?negative at all wavelengths.However the green and red spectral responses for the CAT02 matrix (thick lines in Fig.) havenegative parts.

Furthermore, we report on the performances of the different matrices using the corresponding colour datasets. Tablelists the mean CIELAB colour differences for each corresponding colour data set and the overall weightedmean colour differences in CIELAB units, for the CAT02 matrixM02[Eq.], the HPE matrixMHPE[Eq.] and the new matrixMOPT[Eq.]. The new matrixMOPTgives a weighted mean colour difference of 6.48 CIELAB units over all 21 data sets against 6.77 CIELABunits obtained by the HPE matrixMHPE. Thus, the new matrixMOPTperforms better than the HPE matrix (0.29 CIELAB units lower, on the average), but, unfortunately,comparing with the original CAT02 matrix, the new matrixMOPTperforms worse (1.0 CIELAB units higher, on the average). Anyway, it must be said that this slightlyworse performance is compensated by the very important fact that the newMOPTmatrix simultaneously solves the yellow?blue and purple problems.

Although the accuracy of predictions made by theMHPEandMOPTmatrices is similar (see Table), a further statistical test wasperformed to find out if the difference between these two matrices is significant. For each samplej, the CIELAB colour difference between the visual observation and the predictions made by theMHPEandMOPTmatrices are denoted as ?Esjand ?Ebj, respectively. Let ?Esand ?Ebdenote the vectors formed by all ?Esjand ?Ebj, respectively. The MATLAB functionh?=?ttest(?Es, ?Eb) performed at?test of the null hypothesis that thedifference ?Es??Ebwas a random sample from a normal distribution with mean 0 (equivalent to the mean of ?Esand the mean of ?Ebwere the same) and unknown variance, against the alternative hypothesis that the mean was not 0, at the95% significance level. Test results indicated that predictions made by theMHPEandMOPTmatrices were significantly different over nine data sets, which have been shown via shading in the lastcolumn of Table. In other words, the predictions made by theMHPEandMOPTmatrices were statistically similar over twelve datasets corresponding to the un?shaded values in thelast column of Table. If we group all 21 corresponding colour data setstogether, the predictions made by theMHPEandMOPTmatrices were also found statistically significantly different.

If we further compare the predictions made by theM02andMOPTmatrices, it can be noted from Tablethat theMOPTmatrix performs much worse over the LUTCHI (D65/WF), and Breneman (3), (4), (8), and (9) datasets.Perhaps this is the natural result of adding the nesting constraint to the optimum solution search. Theoptimum is no longer unconstrained, and so the cost function must degrade. On the other hand, it can benoted that the originalM02matrix performs also worse on these five datasets compared with the other data sets, suggestingpotential inconsistencies among different datasets.

Figuresandshow two examples of the visual and predicted colour shifts in CIELABa*,b*plane for the CSAJ and Braun and Fairchild (3) data sets, respectively. The black lines are the visualcolour shifts, the ends with circles corresponding to the original samples under illuminants A/D93 forthe former/latter data set, and the ends without circles the visual matches under illuminant D65. Thefull red and blue lines are the colour shifts predicted by theMHPEandMOPTmatrices, respectively. It can be clearly seen that for most cases the blue lines (predictions made bythe newMOPTmatrix) are between the black (visual results) and red (predictions by theMHPEmatrix) lines, which means that the predictions made by the newMOPTmatrix are more accurate.

Finally, the performance of the modified CIECAM02 has been evaluated using different colour appearancedata sets,which were accumulated at the Loughborough University of Technology Computer?Human Interface (LUTCHI)Research Centre and at the Colour Imaging Institute at University of Derby, and were also used to modelthe original CIECAM022and report its performance.LetPibe the model predictions, andVithe experimental visual results, for a set ofi=1,?,nsamples. TheCVindex defined in Eq. (41)is a coefficient of variation in percentage, considering the modified CIECAM02 predictions on colourcorrelated attributes (i.e., lightness, colourfulness, and hue composition) against observers?experimental visual results:CV=1001n?i=1n(Pi?Vi)2/(1n?i=1nVi)

IfCV?=?0, the agreement between the modifiedCIECAM02 predictions and the experimental visualresults is perfect.CV?=?20 means a 20%disagreement between the modified CIECAM02 predictions andexperimental visual results. The lower theCVis, the better the model performs. Here we will designate asCV¯the mean ofCVvalues for all data sets considered.

CONCLUSIONS

In this article, first the chromatic adaptation matrix and its red, green and blue primaries wereinvestigated. Linear equations linking the matrix coefficients and the chromaticity coordinates of itsprimaries inx,yandu?,v? spaces were given. Based on theseequations, thex,y(oru?,v?) chromaticity coordinates of thered, green and blue primaries can be obtained ifthe matrix is given. Symmetrically, if thex,y(oru?,v?) chromaticity coordinates of thethree primaries are given, the coefficients ofthe matrix can also be determined, which made the foundation for modeling the solution to theyellow?blue and purple problems as an optimization problem. Second, the constraint conditions I), II)and III) for a matrix satisfying the nesting rule were studied, which resulted in the sixx,y(oru?,v?) chromaticity coordinates of thethree primaries can be reduced to twoindependent variablesxGandxR(oru?Gandv?R). Thirdly, while we force the new matrix to satisfy the nesting rule, we also want the new matrix fitsas accurately as possible the corresponding colour data sets, which resulted in a two?variable objectivefunction for optimization. The constrained non?linear optimization problem was solved using MATLAB intheu?,v? andx,ychromaticity spaces, respectively. In either space, it was possible to obtain the local minimum solutionfor each randomly selected initial condition. It was found that for each run the red primary wasstabilized at pointP1(see Figs.and), which is the intersection point of the extended purple line andthe line linking the red and green primary points of the HPE matrix. For the green primary, it was foundthat the experimental corresponding colour data sets are not sensitive to the variableu?Gin the range from ?0.2984 to ?0.2800, and the objective function roughly had the same value. Similarly,the optimization inx,yspace showed that the green primaryxGintended to stabilize at large positive/negative values when the conditions III1)/III2) were used. As shown in a previous article,when point (xG,yG) approaches infinity along the line defined by Eq., the point (u?G,v?G) approaches to point Binf, as shown inFig.and specified in Table. All these results led us to consider the singleoptimum matrixMOPTas the one having primariesP12N?=?P12,P13N?=?Binf,andP23N?=?P1inu?,v? space, with coefficients given inEq.. When predictingthe experimental results in corresponding colour data sets, theMOPTmatrix performed on the average 0.29 CIELAB units better than theMHPEmatrix. Statistically, the predictions of these two matrices are significantly different on nine (out of21) datasets and on all datasets together. However, on the average theMOPTmatrix performed 1.0 CIELAB units worse than the originalM02matrix for the corresponding colour datasets. When predicting lightness in colour appearance data sets,MOPThad the same performance asMHPE, but performed about 0.2CVunits worse than theM02matrix. When predicting colorfulness in colour appearance data sets, it was found thatMOPTperformed about 0.2CVunits better thanMHPE, and 0.1CVunits worse thanM02. When predicting hue composition incolour appearance datasets, it was found thatMOPTperformed almost equally well as theM02, and about 0.1CVunits better thanMHPE. Bearing in mind thatCVvalues were defined in percentages [Eq.], from previous values it canbe concluded that the predictions of colour appearance data sets made by matricesM02,MHPE,andMOPTare very similar.

In all, we must say that we have solved the yellow?blue and purple problems simultaneously, and the newproposed matrixMOPT[Eq.] performs similarly to theMHPEmatrix when predicting both the colour appearance and corresponding colour data sets. Anyway it wasfound that on nine corresponding colour datasets and on all corresponding colour datasets as a whole thepredictions ofMOPTandMHPEmatrices were statistically different, and theMOPTmatrix produced better results. However, for the corresponding colour data sets, the new matrixMOPTperformed slightly worse than the original CAT02 matrixM02(1.0 CIELAB units worse, on the average). Unfortunately, under the current structure of CIECAM02, it wasnot possible to obtain a new CAT02 matrix satisfying the nesting rule and performing equally well orbetter than the original CAT02 matrix for corresponding colour data sets. In any case, the simultaneoussolution of the yellow?blue and purple problems, together with the good prediction of availablecorresponding colours and colour appearance data sets, induce us to propose theMOPT[Eq.] matrix for future CIECAM02 revisions.
